video.title: Great Design With User Research - Design a Mobile App Using Figma
video.description:
Improve your UI / UX design skills by designing a real-world app using Figma. You will learn how to use the d.school design thinking process and self process management to come up with design solutions.

✏️ Course created by Dev and Design. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCETwb_AzizmhID0RjKULnBA

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (0:04:53) Outline Breakdown
⌨️ (0:07:01) Workflow Breakdown In FigJam
⌨️ (0:22:50) User Empathy ( Empathize )
⌨️ (0:23:21) Creating User Experience Survey With Google Forms
⌨️ (0:38:21) Creating User Personas
⌨️ (0:43:08) Creating Problem Statement
⌨️ (0:44:31) Ideate
⌨️ (0:47:49) Prototype Analysis
⌨️ (0:48:16) User Goals & User Tasks
⌨️ (0:50:11) Information Architecture
⌨️ (0:55:38) Low Fidelity Prototyping
⌨️ (1:19:59) High Fidelity Prototyping
⌨️ (1:20:11) Creating Style Library
⌨️ (1:37:21) Creating Component Library
⌨️ (3:32:11) Prototype Presentation & Assignments

🎉 Thanks to our Champion and Sponsor supporters:
👾 Raymond Odero
👾 Agustín Kussrow
👾 aldo ferretti
👾 Otis Morgan
👾 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: tori
topLevelComment.text: would like to see a video in depth on explaining auto layout and setting constraints. when I set an auto layout text to fill content and set another auto layout to fill content, the text will reset to fix. WHY??? as well as how you decide your spacing between elements not just the 8px rule. Is there a set spacing from top of page to first element? is there a rule that elements next to each other is 16px? is there a rule that elements beneath each other is 24px?

topLevelComment.author: tori
topLevelComment.text: 2:40 when I followed your steps it brought the search icon closer to the text and the input box is responsive, but the search icon was not

replies.author: tori
replies.text:
ok i figured this out. for anyone else who was having trouble with this these are the steps that i needed to do.
copy or grab input asset, rt click to detach it, remove auto layout, it now becomes a frame, changed text, find icon, size it, put it in the frame on the side you want. change color of icon, click on whole frame which included input box, text and icon add auto layout then go to advanced settings and change it from packed to space between. now it is responsive. then I made it a component.

topLevelComment.author: Garri R
topLevelComment.text: I never knew the reason for user research. As someone with an engineering/science background, I consider myself able to think of contigencies and redundancies before they happen far better than any user could. Like you want someone who probably doesn't know more than you about UI design to tell you about where a button should be? As Steve Jobs once said, "People don't know what they want until you show them."

replies.author: A P
replies.text: I think you are missing the point. User research is important and all the top tech companies like FAANG utilise user research and considering that one of the top reasons why start-ups fail is because they are creating something that people don't actually want to use really highlights how important user research is but it is also massively overlooked by people like you. For example, if you have an app and you are only 30% of users are going past the landing page, is it because they are confused? Is the information unclear? Does the website look unprofessional? Is the price too high? These are questions can only really be answered by doing user research. A sample size of a group of engineers who know the ins and outs of the project is not useful, you want a potential customer who is discovering this for the first time. What Steve Jobs is referring to is that you need to get your prototype or product in front of the users and see how they interact with it. You can't just ask questions with no basis. In the beginning  that might work to get a general idea but to really move forward you need to evaluate how people are interacting with what you are making.

replies.author: Iftekharul Haque
replies.text:
this tutorial is for designers, not coders, we design design stuff, for example if somebody needs a website or app first they will hire a designer to come up with ideas of what the website or app will look like, after they design the app or site, front end coders come in and turn the design into codes, after that back end developers come in and make the site or app functional, think of it like building a house, we designers are like engineers who make the blueprint, the front end coders build on that blueprint, however building the house isn't enough, it needs things like water, electricity, furniture and so on, the backend coders make the building functional by for example getting the building access to water and electricity. this is my understanding after studying for the past two months, anybody reading this correct me if i am wrong.
if you want to change careers, you could learn designing, start with simple stuff, like flyers and business cards, then work your way up, of course you will need a computer for these things. good luck
